en.sc1: Suppose method a() has a call to method b().
en.sc2: method b() then has a call to method c().
en.sc3: method c() then has a call to method d().
en.sc4: Once method d() is done, what happens next?
en.sc8: You can think of going from a() to d() as the 'winding' for a series of method calls...
en.sc9: and returning back to a() as the 'unwinding'.
en.sc10: The same thing happens with all methods. Recursive methods are no different from non-recursive methods in how they behave.
en.sc11: Suppose method f() makes a recursive call to method f()...
en.sc12: ...which makes a call to method f()...
en.sc13: ...which eventually makes a call to method f() that triggers the base case.
en.sc14: Once reaching the base case, it will then unwind to the previous instance of f()...
en.sc16: ...and finally back to the original f().
